I'd say this game is great if you just focus on the main parts of the game and just enjoy your time with what you have.
However, if you want to play stuff that isn't included stock... well, your wallet definitely won't be thanking you any time soon.

The music is pretty good, I'd say for every, "Meh, it's okay," you'll have two, "Dang, that's pretty good." But to get that "WOW" feeling, you better cough up some of your precious dollars. This is because the songs that come with the game seem almost specifically designed to be a level or two below the paid content; not enough to really upset you, but just enough to sort of bug you. This will inevitably lead to you buying at least one of the DLC that you simply don't need. All of that knocks off a good chunk of the out-of-ten score.

If you're okay with spending money on what is, admittedly, a decent variety of songs (even if it's an objectively bad deal), then you'll have a really good experience. It's not just the songs that are better; the mapping is, too. The maps in the base-game are alright, but most of them lack a certain level of enjoyment. The DLC maps fix that, in my opinion, bringing the count of really good or enjoyable maps from 1 in 5 to 1 in 3 (or even 1 in 2). The DLC is definitely high quality from what I've seen.

But don't fret over that high price-tag as I once did. There are plenty of sales throughout each year to really enable your addiction to spending, with packs plummeting from around $30 (CAD) to just $7; sometimes, the prices can get even lower than that, so keep an eye out.

Hope this review helped someone. Thanks for reading :)

Core Keeper is pretty good, its basically horizontal Terraria, and for the 1.0 release its pretty alright. 
The combat isn't excessively difficult, and the boss fights feel rewarding. 
That being said it has some major problems. Magic and Summoning are nearly useless as combat classes, with them being pointlessly difficult to level and the weapons being not as good as their range and melee counterparts. I initially started the game trying to play as a mage, but had to switch to range because mana regeneration never was decent enough during boss fights. In fact during most of the game the only decent combat class is range, with melee only being good late game with the stormbringer since early game melee is suicidal almost. Making the game play feel restricting. 
The other non combat skills are fine, I think how they are leveled should be re balanced since I think having to craft 10,000 stone bridges was kinda boring and lame. Instead I think more XP in general should be given when you kill a higher ranked enemy, fish a higher ranked fish, or craft a higher ranked item, making it so that players are not forced to grind easy things since they give just as much XP as higher ranked things. If these skills worked like that then, my point still stands since there was not a noticeable enough of a difference to make me want to consider changing tactics. 
My other gripe can be forgiven since its the 1.0 release is the the lack of vanity items, there exists like 5 sets and a few hats, mostly locked behind seasonal events, but that's it, I think for a game with so much personality there should be more options available for the player. 
Overall, fun initial experience but gets kinda worthlessly grindy for late game when played normally.

I used to wonder why nobody ever made a top-down "Zelda-type Terraria/Minecraft".
Well, Core Keeper (CK) basically fills that role, which I absolutely love. Tons of bosses, huge procedural world map, and lots of different gear and progression, with extensive crafting and house building features. The game even pays tribute to Terraria with certain easter eggs (such as King Slime). I'm actually surprised by how good (and fun) CK actually is, compared to what I expected from "just another indie title".

By comparison, Stardew Valley has a similar Zelda-like art style, but is far more focused around farming, social simulation, and timed events. CK has farming as well, but it generally goes more in the vein of Terraria's more combat-heavy gameplay, which I personally prefer. As for the combat, CK feels very smooth, tactile and responsive (something I felt Starbound lacked, to name another similar game).

Another side feature that I like is the ability to find special ore-heavy boulders that you can mine out with basic automation features (conveyor belts and mining drills), even though this game isn't primarily about factory automation. Think of it more as a kind of "redstone system" that supports the rest of the game - simple, yet useful. You will, however, be spending most of your early- to mid game digging manually through rocks, which itself isn't too bad but can feel grindy at times. I personally had issues finding Tin Ore reliably but, other than that, my first 15 hours haven't been too annoying or boring. (Besides, just today I found 2 Tin Ore boulders close to each other that are now spewing loads of tin in my general direction in ways that only Prince would sing about.)

Overall, I give this game two huge thumbs up. Highly Recommended, especially for fans of Terraria and similar games!

TL:DR I love this game. Best 15$ I have spent on a game in YEARS. If I knew how good it was back then, I would have payed 100 for it. 

So I have finally beat this game. After nearly 100 hours of game play. Some of which was spent in a friends world, but most of it was just mine. I thoroughly enjoyed every aspect of this game. The farming, the crafting, mining, fishing, the different combat styles, everything. The music and art is top tier. Every zone is a breath of fresh air when it comes to music and design, and it brought the atmosphere of each zone together in a way that not many games are able to pull off. 

I absolutely loved all of the boss fights. I did end up having a fairly cheesy build that made a lot of them a lot more trivial than they should have been, but because of this I am genuinely looking forward to playing through again, but with a much less cheesy build. I honestly had no idea what the final boss was, and literally finished it 5 mins prior to this review. 

I would like the genuinely thank the minds behind this game, the people who brought it to life in such a beautifully crafted way, because I believe this is easily a top 10 game I have played in my 25ish years of playing games. So thank you very very much Pugstorm. This is a solid 100/10 for me, and I genuinely hope that more people get to experience the simplistic bliss that is this game.
This game has a DEEP bag.

Many of the core mechanics are simply very fun to do - farming, fishing, combat, even cooking. I loved getting to experiment with different builds, and experiment with different recipes to make buffs to complement those builds. Bosses are decently fun, but the progression as a whole is really where the game shines. I was really excited to see just what I could fish up when I got to a new area, or what items the enemies dropped.

I heard about Core Keeper during the official release sale and picked it up. I am so glad that I did. It has been a long time since I have found a game that has pulled me in like this one has. The game play loop of exploration, looting, base building, and all the other systems and mechanics is quite satisfying. I love the fact that there is no hand holding and no pressure to accomplish objectives other than the allure to explore and experiment. 

At present I have been enjoying hopping worlds with my main character and setting up resource harvesting for my main world. I have just discovered automation and the order that can bring. I have since bought a copy for each of my children and we are all playing on a dedicated server I am hosting in my home. It has become one of our favorite pass times now.

The only gripe I have, and it is minor, is inventory management. I think like many this can be done better. Primarily a way of dealing with seeds and decorative plants. It would also be nice to have a larger radius for pulling resources from chests when crafting.

Core Keeper is a great game. I am already 66 hours in and it has flown by. I can see myself playing this game for hundreds of hours and not getting bored.

Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney Trilogy is a charming saga in an anime-lite world of a defense attorney defending eccentric clients and unraveling mysteries in a visual novel/point-and-click adventure game. The game's main strengths are its characters, story, writing, and music, which create something greater than the sum of its parts. I highly recommend this game to people looking to see the best of the visual novel genre, games that emulate legal/detective TV drama shows, people just curious what the franchise is about, and people who enjoy story rich games and logic puzzles.

My only complaint is that it takes a long time to play through these games, with each episode taking up a day easily. For a 100% playthrough, it took me just under 100 hours. This might play better on a mobile device, like a Steam Deck or other platforms, where you pick up and play in bites than sitting at a computer the whole time, but that was not my experience. At the very least, you owe it to yourself to at least play the first game in the series, Ace Attorney, which has the best story, pacing, and writing of the 3, in my opinion. None of the 3 are stinkers, so if you enjoy the first, you'll enjoy all of them.

This is a very well done and faithful remake to the original games.

I do recommend this game, however I think the DS version still stands taller than this great game.

There were just some things that gave much more charm to the game on that platform, for example:
- The fingerprint mini-game has you tapping powder on the bottom screen with the stylus, and blowing into the mic to clear it
- Separating the interaction buttons on the lower screen, with the upper screen used completely for characters and dialog

I went in expecting something similar to Katana Zero, but it's so much more than that. Saying Sanabi is a Katana Zero clone would be a huge disservice to this game. To me, both are exceptional gems.

But before I continue to sing my praises to this game, what exactly is Sanabi?

Well, in this action platformer game, you play as a retired veteran with a simple mission, which is to hunt an entity called "Sanabi". To do this, you will use your chain hook prosthetic arm to get around a city called Mago. This weapon can also be used to hook yourself to the enemies, destroying them in the process.

This grappling hook mechanism means that you will spend most of your time in the air, going from one platform to another, from one enemy to another, from one boss to another. And when done right, it feels oh so good, especially because of the tight movement. Makes you feel unstoppable, and it gets the adrenaline pumping!

I said "when done right", because at first, I struggled getting used to the grappling hook gameplay and gamepad controls. Because not only you can hook the enemy, you can boost yourself, slow down time, jump, and so much more. But overtime, I learned to get good and finally experienced that flow state.

Surprisingly, even with this addicting gameplay formula, my favorite part of Sanabi is still the story. Without spoiling anything, you will be confused at first because of the mysteries surrounding Sanabi and Mago are pretty complicated, but once you connect the dots, it will be mind blowing. 

At least mine did, that's for sure. It makes me want to replay the whole game instantly to see all the hints I missed.

Not only mind blowing, Sanabi's story has a lot of heart thanks to its characters. Mind you, Sanabi doesn't have too many characters, since you spend most of your time with a hacker girl named Mari, who's helping you find Sanabi, and her robot companion Mufin.

While Mari might be too talkative to some, I found her character very charming, I really enjoyed her funny personality and antics, and I think the game definitely won't be the same without Mari.

I was too invested in the story of Sanabi, the retired veteran, and Mari. By the end of the game, I was left sobbing my eyes out, heck, I instantly went to write a review, three years after I wrote my previous review.

All of these positive points, combined with the epic soundtracks and the eye catching pixel art, makes the game a complete package worth checking out, even in full price. Scratch that, I insist YOU to try out this game if you love some fast paced action gameplay and heart tugging storytelling.

With that being said, to Wonder Potion a.k.a the developers, I'll be looking forward to your future games! Doesn't matter if it will start as an Early Access product again, I WILL be there!

I have to give this a very reluctant thumbs up.  This is a very good game, but it is certainly not a game that deserves an "Overwhelmingly Positive" tag.  Here's why:

(1) The best part of this game is the story; there is little doubt about that. Though the story is very good, it is absolutely not original, as it is basically an exact copy of a couple very specific movies. Still, the story is worth getting through. I suggest you don't read anything about it and just go through it without any spoilers of any type, even the trailers.

(2) The problem with this "game" is that there is too much emphasis on the story.  You will spend significantly more time watching cut scenes and reading dialogue than actually playing.  That sounds like an exaggeration, but it is 100% true. There is LESS TIME SPENT ON GAMEPLAY THAN ON CUT SCENES. 

(3) The game took some obvious inspiration from Bionic Commando.  Swinging around is fun, but that is basically all you do.  There is little combat here and it is as simplistic as you can possibly get while still calling this a game. 

(4) It way too easy. The challenge of the game is figuring out and becoming adept with the controls.  Once you do that, you fly through the game with ease. 

Some of the reviews compare this to Katana Zero, even saying that it is better than Katana Zero.  I don't think this game is playing in the same league as Katana Zero.  Katana Zero is a far superior game. 

This could have been a legitimate classic if there was more time spent on gameplay and less on cut scenes. This game is a B.  I am not suggesting that you should not play it, as it has its fun parts, but this is really more a movie than a video game.

I will say though that the English localization is pretty meh, it's like FF Tactics War of the Lions on the PSP, added sentences that weren't present in the original and using out of place archaisms. I'd recommend this game to anyone looking for a SRPG with a good lengthy story and challenging battles.

The "tactical" battles are quite shallow and only require a little bit of strategy for a couple of very specific encounters on Hard mode, and the most interesting combat decisions you'll ever make only has to do with one very specific ending, where you split up your characters into 3 teams. Otherwise, only buy this if your enjoyment comes from the branching stories and having to persuade your party into going along with your decisions.

The SRPG gameplay was fun. There's an emphasis on flanking mechanics, which I found interesting. Character progression and customization is somewhat limited, which I didn't really mind. (I wasn't interested in figuring out super complicated custom character builds.) Part of the fun comes from having a huge roster, and picking the right characters for each battle. The problem with this is that the game is rather stingy with character upgrade materials, so you end up focusing on just a few characters to upgrade. There are four potential endings to the game, including one true ending that is pretty much impossible to get on a first run. I HATE it when games expect you to play NG+.

Noting, I never once felt that I couldn't get the party to "swing my way" with the votes, but even still, there are some tough choices, and as some of the situations come to a head you'll wish you had a magic wand to right all the wrongs because you know the world is set up to where you can make a difference but you can't save everyone, do everything right, and that's gonna make you play it over again OR follow a guide to get the golden ending. 

I did know there was a golden ending, and I thought I should possibly follow a guide to get it, but I was having too much fun choosing my answers blindly. The only painful thing is, as an adult, it's hard to find the time to beat one game that takes 100 hours much less beating it over again, but some gems are worth it! I barely had any playtime with my favorite character (Prince Roland's sister, Cordelia), and I see from the achievements that she's a playable character? Not on my first try, she wasn't! So, of course, I'm going to play it over again. And I want to see the best ending, because now I care about the world and the characters. The story tone is more serious than I'm used to when I think of a typical jrpg, somber, and there isn't a lot of comedy, but it works well for the setting.

If you like strategy games and jrpg storylines, give this one a try!

This is a great tactical game and I feel a great successor to final fantasy tactics. The most common complaint right off is that there is a lot of story. The tactical game is interesting and balanced through NG. I have not gone farther than two play throughs so can't comment on other runs, but so far the scaling does not take anything away nor does it feel like just bigger numbers. 

Every character feels viable in some way, some are easier to determine their use and feel more powerful right off but with a little bit of experimenting everyone has a strong case to be in the party. Some characters may feel more useful over time as they are leveled up or playing at higher levels as well. At all times it was difficult to not want to take everybody but for some levels with the terrain and start positions some characters really would shine. 

I am a big fan of tactics game but I do lean hard into needing a good story to make each battle feel good. This game his great theme music for each character and specific places, acceptable voice acting, and just looks great and plays great. 

I wouldn't let the length of story cut scenes scare you off, if you enjoy any kind of political maneuvering in your story it's a great one that'll will add a lot of context to the battles you are fighting while also getting to play around with some great combat that has a strong emphasis on positioning. If you enjoyed FF Tactics and are looking for something close to it, this would be one of the best modern takes on the genre.

Cons
